{{Infobox Stadium | stadium_name = Livestrong Sporting Park | nickname = | image = [[File:Livestrong Sporting Park.png|200px]]

[[File:SportingKC Stadium.jpg|220x220px]] | location = [[Kansas City, Kansas|Kansas City]], [[Kansas|KS]] | capacity = 18,467 (soccer){{Cite web|url=http://www.livestrongsportingpark.com/sporting-club-and-cisco-unveil-next-generation-fan-experience-at-livestrong-sporting-park/|title=Sporting Club and Cisco Unveil Next Generation Fan Experience at LIVESTRONG Sporting Park|date=7 June 2011|accessdate=10 June 2011|publisher=LIVESTRONG Sporting Park}}
25,000 (concerts) | coordinates = {{coord|39.1218|-94.8237|type:landmark_scale:2000|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = January 20, 2010 | opened = June 9, 2011 | closed = | demolished = | owner = Kansas Unified Development, LLC. | operator = [[Global Spectrum]]{{Cite web|url=http://www.sportsbusinessdaily.com/Journal/Issues/2011/06/20/Facilities/Livestrong.aspx|title=Strong debut|publisher=Street and Smith's Sportsbusiness Journal|accessdate=18 October 2011}} | surface = Grass | construction_cost = $200 million
(${{formatprice|{{Inflation|US|200000000|2011}}}} in {{CURRENTYEAR}} dollars{{inflation-fn|US}}) | architect = [[Populous (architects)|Populous]]{{Cite web|url=http://portfolio.populous.com/projects/sportingkc.html|title=LIVESTRONG Sporting Park|publisher=Populous.com|accessdate=10 June 2011}} | structural engineer = [[Thornton Tomasetti]] | general_contractor = [[Turner Construction]] | dimensions = 120 x 75 yards | former_names = | tenants = [[Sporting Kansas City]] ([[Major League Soccer|MLS]]) (2011â ) |}} '''Livestrong Sporting Park''' is a [[soccer-specific stadium]] in [[Kansas City, Kansas|Kansas City]], [[Kansas]] and is the home of [[Sporting Kansas City]]. The stadium opened during the [[2011 Major League Soccer season|2011 season]] of [[Major League Soccer]] on June 9, 2011 with a match against the [[Chicago Fire Soccer Club|Chicago Fire]].{{Cite web|url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/report/_/id/312888?cc=5901|title=Sporting KC settles for 0â0 draw with Fire|accessdate=10 June 2011|date=9 June 2011|publisher=ESPN.com}} The stadium has a seating capacity of 18,467 seats, which can expand to 25,000 for concerts.{{Cite web|url=http://www.forbes.com/feeds/ap/2011/06/09/business-financial-impact-soc-livestrong-sporting-park_8507939.html|title=KC unveils $200 million new soccer stadium|last=Tucker|first=Doug|publisher=Forbes.com|accessdate=10 June 2011|date=9 June 2011}} The stadium is Sporting Kansas City's third home venue. The team played in [[Arrowhead Stadium]] from 1996 to 2007 and [[CommunityAmerica Ballpark]] from 2008 to 2010. ==History== ===Initial planning=== Originally, [[Sporting Club]], the team's ownership group, planned to move to southeast [[Kansas City, Missouri]] on land previously occupied by Bannister Mall. The redevelopment plan, called [[The Trails]], was passed on December 13, 2007.http://primebuzz.kcstar.com/?q=node/8940 As expected, City Council gives final approval to Three Trails project The last package of economic incentives, a $30-million tax rebate, was passed on November 21, 2008. The stadium's planned site had been demolished to prepare the site for infrastructure. It was intended to open in 2011 with a capacity of 18,500 seats. However, fallout from the 2008â2009 financial crisis placed the project on hiatus, and the stadium developer eventually sought to move the new project near the Village West retail center in [[Kansas City, Kansas]], near the [[Kansas Speedway]] and [[CommunityAmerica Ballpark]].{{cite news|url=http://www.kansascity.com/703/story/1433346.html?storylink=omni_popular |title=Wizards stadium project kicked over the state line to Wyandotte County |first=Kevin |last=Collison |publisher=''[[The Kansas City Star]]'' |date=2009-09-08 |accessdate=2009-09-13}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} The developer of The Trails complex sought additional "enhancements" (i.e., borrowing authority) from Kansas City to finance the building of the soccer stadium and its associated amateur soccer complex. However, the city was unwilling to provide the desired financing, leading the developer to seek a new site across the state line.{{Citation needed|date= June 2011}} ===Construction=== [[File:Farm Aid 2011 - Dave Matthews and Tim Reynolds - Livestrong Sporting Park KCK.jpg|left|thumb|[[Dave Matthews]] and [[Tim Reynolds]] performed at [[Farm Aid]] at Livestrong Sporting Park on August 13, 2011.]] In September 2009, the developer asked [[Wyandotte County, Kansas|Wyandotte County]] and [[Kansas]] state officials for permission to use revenues from existing [[tax increment financing]] in the [[Village West]] area to help finance the soccer complex.[http://www.kansascity.com/sports/wizards/story/1619544.html Kansas adjusts offer aimed at spurring Cerner, Wizards development near speedway], The Kansas City Star, December 08, 2009. On December 17, Sporting KC president, Robb Heineman provided an update on the stadium situation published on team official website and blog,[http://kc.wizards.mlsnet.com/news/team_news.jsp?ymd=20091217&content_id=7825974&vkey=pr_kcw&fext=.jsp&team=t105 Heineman provides stadium update], KC Wizards Official Website.[http://www.hillcrestroadblog.com/2009/12/rh-stadium-update.html Hillcrest Road â RH Stadium Update], OnGoal CEO/Wizards President Robb Heineman gives an update on the progress of the stadium project. basically putting the Kansas City, Kansas location as final, pending the signature of the final agreements. On the 21st of December, construction machinery was already on the Legends site waiting to break ground on the site.[http://www.hillcrestroadblog.com/2009/12/yellow-machines-on-site.html Hillcrest Road â Yellow Machines on Site], Equipment from Clarkson Construction showed up at the future site of the stadium in KCK.[http://kansascity.bizjournals.com/kansascity/stories/2009/12/21/daily35.html Work starts on Kansas City Wizards stadium], Kansas City Business Journal â by Rob Roberts. On January 19, Wyandotte County approved the bonds to help finance the stadium,[http://kc.wizards.mlsnet.com/news/team_news.jsp?ymd=20100119&content_id=7938772&vkey=pr_kcw&fext=.jsp&team=t105 Stadium Approval News], Sporting KC Official Website. and on the 20th, the groundbreaking ceremony happened with Sporting's CEO, Robb Heineman, using heavy machinery to move dirt on the construction site.[http://www.hillcrestroadblog.com/2010/01/dirt-has-moved.html Stadium Ground Breaking], Wizards Official Blog. ===Inaugural season=== The opening match took place on June 9, 2011, as Sporting played the [[Chicago Fire SC|Chicago Fire]] to a scoreless draw. The first goal would come days later during the [[2011 CONCACAF Gold Cup]] when [[Dwayne De Rosario]] converted a penalty kick for [[Canada national soccer team|Canada]] against [[Panama national football team|Panama]]. Sporting's first goal came from [[C. J. Sapong]] in a 1–0 win over the [[San Jose Earthquakes]], the club's first victory in the stadium. Sporting would finish its first regular season in the stadium with a 9–2–6 record at home. ==International matches== Livestrong Sporting Park hosted its first international match with the final Group C matches of the 2011 CONCACAF Gold Cup. Canada and Panama played to a 1–1 draw in this match, which was followed by the stadium's first-ever [[United States men's national soccer team|USA]] match, a 1-0 win over [[Guadeloupe national football team|Guadeloupe]]. The stadium played host to its first-ever women's match when it hosted the [[United States women's national soccer team]] in its first match since the [[2011 FIFA Women's World Cup]], a 1–1 draw with [[Canada women's national soccer team|Canada]] witnessed by a crowd of 16,191. Livestrong Sporting Park will play host to the semifinals and final of the [[2012 CONCACAF Men's Pre-Olympic Tournament]].http://www.kansascity.com/2011/11/10/3259643/olympic-qualifying-games-coming.html Olympics ===Men's matches=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Date ! Result ! Date ! Result ! Competition |- | 17 September 2011 || {{fb|USA}} 1â1 {{fb|CAN}} || Friendly |- |} ==Stadium naming rights== On March 8, 2011 a partnership with [[Lance Armstrong]]'s [[Lance Armstrong Foundation|Livestrong]] foundation was announced. The club will donate a portion of revenues, no less than $7.5 million, to the foundation over the course of six years.{{Cite news|url=http://www.kansascity.com/2011/06/08/2937333/sporting-president-heineman-is.html#storylink=misearch|title=Sporting president Heineman is eager for opening of Livestrong Sporting Park|last=McCollough|first=Brady|date=8 June 2011|accessdate=10 June 2011|publisher=''The Kansas City Star''}} ==Attendance Records== The November 6, 2011 game against the [[Houston Dynamo]] set a home attendance record of 20,839 including standing room only tickets.http://www.sportingkc.com/news/2011/11/recap-skc-season-ends-eastern-conference-final ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== *[http://www.livestrongsportingpark.com/ Livestrong Sporting Park (official website)] *[http://sportingkc.io-media.com/ Virtual Venue view of seating] {{Sporting Kansas City}} {{MLS Stadiums}} {{2011 CONCACAF Gold Cup venues}} [[Category:Sporting Kansas City]] [[Category:Major League Soccer stadiums]] [[Category:Soccer venues in Kansas]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Kansas City, Kansas]] [[Category:Visitor attractions in Wyandotte County, Kansas]] [[ca:Livestrong Sporting Park]] [[de:Livestrong Sporting Park]] [[es:Livestrong Sporting Park]] [[fr:Livestrong Sporting Park]] [[hy:Ô¼Õ«Õ¾Õ½Õ©ÖÕ¸Õ¶Õ£ ÕÕºÕ¸ÖÕ¿Õ«Õ¶Õ£ ÕÕ¡ÖÕ¯]]
